# üí° DM TIPS & REFERENCE GUIDE

**[LOAD PRIORITY: REFERENCE ‚Äî Load for general DM advice and collected wisdom]**

---

## Purpose

This file collects practical DM advice, tips, and wisdom from across The Architect v2.5 system. Load this when you need inspiration, guidance, or reminders.

Tag: `[DM TIPS: practical advice for running The Architect system effectively]`

---

## Core Philosophy Reminders

### The Three Pillars of The Architect

1. **Fictional Positioning First**: What makes narrative sense?
2. **Consequence Over Plot**: Let actions ripple naturally
3. **Scarcity Creates Meaning**: Not everything at maximum intensity

### The Iron Rule

**Never sacrifice player agency for your plot.**

If your planned story requires PCs to fail, surrender, or miss something critical:
- You're railroading
- Redesign so player choice matters
- Multiple paths to information/goals

Tag: `[CORE PHILOSOPHY: fictional positioning, consequence, scarcity, agency]`

---

## Generation Wisdom

### When to Generate vs. Improvise

**Generate When**:
- Element will recur (NPCs, locations)
- Need depth and consistency
- Have time between sessions
- Creating campaign foundations

**Improvise When**:
- One-off encounters
- Minor background elements
- In-session surprise needs
- Time-sensitive response

**Rule of Thumb**: If PCs will see it again, generate it properly.

Tag: `[GENERATION TIMING: generate recurring, improvise one-offs]`

### The Depth Allocation Principle

**Don't over-generate**:
- Not every NPC needs Full Depth
- Not every location needs 6 sensory registers
- Not every faction needs complete relationship web

**Match depth to importance**:
- Major recurring NPCs ‚Üí Full Depth
- Supporting cast ‚Üí Sketch
- Background ‚Üí Mention only

**Campaign budgets**:
- One-Shot: 1-2 Full NPCs
- Short Arc: 3-4 Full NPCs
- Full Campaign: 8-12 Full NPCs

Tag: `[DEPTH ALLOCATION: match generation depth to element importance and campaign format]`

---

## Session Management

### The Session Flow

**Standard 3-4 Hour Session**:
1. **Recap** (5 min): Remind what happened
2. **Opening** (20 min): Low intensity, setup
3. **Development** (90 min): Rising action
4. **Climax** (45 min): Peak intensity
5. **Falling Action** (20 min): Cool down
6. **Preview** (10 min): Hook for next time

**Pacing tip**: Check the clock every 30 minutes. Are you on track?

Tag: `[SESSION FLOW: follow emotional arc from opening to climax to closing]`

### When Sessions Go Off Track

**PCs Ignore Your Plot**:
- ‚úÖ Roll with it, see where they go
- ‚úÖ Adapt your content to their choice
- ‚ùå Force them back on railroad

**Sessions End Early**:
- Downtime RP
- Shopping and crafting
- Relationship building
- Preview next session

**Sessions Run Long**:
- Find natural cliffhanger
- Pause mid-combat (controversial but works)
- Schedule continuation

Tag: `[SESSION FLEXIBILITY: adapt to PC choices, find natural stopping points]`

### The "Yes, And" Principle

When PCs propose creative solutions:

**Player**: "Can I swing from the chandelier?"

**Bad Response**: "No, that won't work"
**Good Response**: "Yes, roll Acrobatics. If you succeed, you gain advantage on your attack"

**Always look for ways to say YES with conditions or consequences.**

Tag: `[YES AND: find ways to enable creative player ideas with appropriate challenges]`

---

## NPC Management

### Making NPCs Memorable

**The Three-Tag Rule**:
Give every NPC three distinctive tags:
1. Physical: "One-eyed veteran"
2. Personality: "Gruff but kindhearted"
3. Speech quirk: "Calls everyone 'youngster'"

That's enough. Players will remember.

Tag: `[NPC MEMORABLE: three distinctive tags make NPCs stick in mind]`

### NPC Voices and Consistency

**Don't do accents if you can't maintain them**:
- Better to describe accent than perform badly
- "She speaks with thick northern accent"
- Use distinctive word choices instead

**Pick one speech pattern and stick to it**:
- Formal vs. colloquial
- Fast-talking vs. taciturn
- Distinctive vocabulary

Tag: `[NPC VOICES: consistency matters more than performance quality]`

### When Players Love an NPC

**Signs**:
- Ask about NPC unprompted
- Seek them out
- Reference them often
- Care about their wellbeing

**Response**:
- Give that NPC more screen time
- Develop their trajectory
- Let relationship deepen
- Don't kill them casually (unless for major impact)

Tag: `[BELOVED NPCs: recognize when players attach, give more development]`

---

## Faction and Plot Management

### The Living Clock Sweet Spot

**Too Slow**: Faction never advances, feels static
**Too Fast**: Faction reaches endgame before PCs engage
**Just Right**: Advances every 2-4 sessions, creates urgency but not rush

**Tip**: If PCs ignore faction, advance clock faster (creating pressure)

Tag: `[CLOCK PACING: advance every 2-4 sessions, faster if PCs ignore]`

### The Plot Thread Limit

**Maximum active threads**:
- One-Shot: 1 thread
- Short Arc: 2-3 threads
- Full Campaign: 4-6 threads

**More than this = overwhelmed players and DM**

**If exceeding**: Resolve, merge, or explicitly table some threads

Tag: `[THREAD LIMIT: max 4-6 active threads in full campaign, resolve excess]`

### The Illusion of Choice

**Sometimes you need to consolidate paths**:

Example: Players need to reach MacGuffin. Three possible approaches:
- Sneak in castle
- Negotiate with lord
- Assault castle

**Behind scenes**: All lead to MacGuffin encounter, but approach determines:
- Who's present
- Starting positions
- NPC dispositions

**Players feel agency, you reduce prep**

**Balance**: Don't make ALL choices illusory (players notice)

Tag: `[FLEXIBLE PLANNING: multiple paths to same outcome, approach affects conditions]`

---

## Information and Mystery Management

### The Three-Clue Rule

**For every mystery, provide at least THREE paths to critical information**:

If PCs MUST learn "villain is duke's brother":
- Clue 1: Duke's portrait shows family resemblance
- Clue 2: Old servant mentions duke's brother disappeared
- Clue 3: Villain has duke's family signet ring

**Why three**: Players miss clues. Three ensures solution accessible.

Tag: `[THREE CLUE RULE: provide multiple paths to critical information]`

### The Breadcrumb Trail

**For long-term mysteries**:
1. Plant subtle hints early
2. Add more obvious clues midway
3. Reveal or let PCs piece together

**Timing**: Space reveals across 3-5 sessions minimum

**Don't hide too well**: If players should know something, make sure they CAN know it

Tag: `[BREADCRUMB TRAIL: progressive reveal from subtle to obvious across sessions]`

### When Players Wildly Speculate

**Player Theory Wrong but Interesting**:
- Consider adopting it (if doesn't break story)
- "Quantum truth" ‚Äî it's true because they guessed
- Makes players feel clever

**Player Theory Wrong and Not Useful**:
- Don't confirm or deny
- Drop more breadcrumbs toward truth
- Let them discover naturally

**Never Say**: "No, you're wrong" (discourages speculation)
**Better**: "Interesting theory. Let's find out."

Tag: `[PLAYER THEORIES: consider adopting interesting theories, never shut down speculation]`

---

## Combat and Encounter Management

### The Interesting Battlefield Rule

**Minimum battlefield elements**: 2 of 5 (cover, hazard, elevation, mobility, objective)

**Why**: Featureless rooms = boring combats

**Quick fixes**:
- Add pillar or debris (cover)
- Fire spreading or pit (hazard)
- Balcony or stairs (elevation)
- Chandeliers or ropes (mobility)
- Rescue hostage or stop ritual (objective)

Tag: `[INTERESTING BATTLEFIELDS: always include at least 2 interactive terrain elements]`

### When Combat Drags

**Signs**:
- Players checking phones
- "I attack again" (repetitive)
- Combat exceeds 45 minutes for standard encounter

**Emergency fixes**:
- Reinforcements arrive (escalate)
- Enemies flee or surrender (end)
- Environmental hazard activates (new dynamic)
- Boss enters next phase (shift)

**Prevention**: Use minions, interesting environments, clear objectives

Tag: `[COMBAT PACING: if dragging, escalate or end, prevent with variety]`

### The Mercy Rule

**If fight becomes unwinnable for PCs**:
- Enemy offers surrender terms
- Ally NPC intervenes
- Environmental change shifts balance
- PCs can retreat

**Never TPK without offering outs** (unless agreed at session zero)

Tag: `[COMBAT MERCY: offer outs if fight becomes hopeless, prevent unwinnable TPK]`

---

## Emotional and Tone Management

### The Emotional Contrast Rule

**After intense (HOT/BURNING)**:
- Must drop to COOL or COLD for at least 15 minutes
- Rest beat required
- Players need processing time

**After rest (COLD)**:
- Can ramp quickly to WARM or HOT
- Provides energy contrast

**Never**: Two BURNING sessions in a row without break

Tag: `[EMOTIONAL CONTRAST: rest after intensity, vary temperature within and across sessions]`

### Reading the Room

**Signs players need break**:
- Disengaged
- Quiet
- Frustrated
- Overwhelmed

**Response**:
- Insert rest beat (shopping, RP, downtime)
- Call 10-minute real break
- End session early if needed
- Next session lighter tone

**Trust your gut**: If it feels heavy, it probably is

Tag: `[READING ROOM: watch for disengagement, insert breaks or lighten tone]`

### The Tragedy Budget

**Rule**: Limit major tragedies
- One-Shot: Maybe 1 if central to story
- Short Arc: 1-2 major tragedies
- Full Campaign: 3-5 major tragedies across entire campaign

**Major tragedy**: Beloved NPC death, devastating defeat, horrific consequence

**Why limit**: Too much tragedy = emotional exhaustion, grimdark fatigue

**Emotional Scarcity Rule applies to tragedy too**

Tag: `[TRAGEDY BUDGET: limit major tragedies, approximately 1 per 5-10 sessions maximum]`

---

## Consequence Management

### The Proportional Consequence Rule

**Match consequence to action**:

Minor action ‚Üí Minor consequence
- "You insulted noble" ‚Üí "Noble refuses to help"

Moderate action ‚Üí Moderate consequence
- "You killed bandit leader" ‚Üí "Bandits seek revenge"

Major action ‚Üí Major consequence
- "You burned down city district" ‚Üí "City guard hunts you, refugees suffer"

**Don't over-punish**: Small mistakes ‚Üí small consequences

Tag: `[PROPORTIONAL CONSEQUENCES: severity matches action, avoid over-punishment]`

### The Positive Consequence Reminder

**Not all consequences are negative**:
- Helped NPC ‚Üí NPC helps back
- Defeated villain ‚Üí Region safer, people grateful
- Resolved conflict ‚Üí Factions become allies

**Track positive consequences too** in Consequence Web

Tag: `[POSITIVE CONSEQUENCES: track rewards and benefits, not only punishments]`

### When to Release Consequences

**Immediate**: Within same session
- Combat damage, social response, immediate danger

**Short-term**: 1-2 sessions later
- NPC seeking revenge, news spreading, repairs needed

**Long-term**: 3+ sessions later
- World state changes, faction shifts, generational effects

**Don't forget**: Set reminders, track in Consequence queue

Tag: `[CONSEQUENCE TIMING: immediate, short-term (1-2 sessions), long-term (3+ sessions)]`

---

## Reward Management

### The Desire-Match Principle

**Know what players want** (from session zero):
- Power (mechanical advancement)
- Treasure (wealth, items)
- Challenge (difficult encounters)
- Emotion (meaningful scenes)
- Story (narrative progression)
- Glory (recognition, fame)
- Discovery (new locations, secrets)
- Connection (NPC relationships)

**Provide all types, emphasize player preferences**

**If player disengaged**: Check reward match

Tag: `[REWARD MATCHING: provide reward types aligned with player desires]`

### The Legendary Item Rule

**Don't give legendary items casually**:
- Find/Earn, not purchase
- Tied to story and quest
- Feels earned, not random

**When giving**:
- Context and history
- Emotional resonance
- Appropriate power level

Tag: `[LEGENDARY ITEMS: earned through story, not purchased, tied to narrative]`

---

## Failure and Setback Management

### How to Handle PC Failure

**PCs Fail Quest**:
- ‚úÖ Show consequences, allow recovery
- ‚úÖ New quest emerges from failure
- ‚ùå Campaign ends, nothing to be done

**PCs Make Bad Choice**:
- ‚úÖ Follow consequences naturally
- ‚úÖ Allow course correction
- ‚ùå Punish indefinitely

**PCs Defeated in Combat**:
- ‚úÖ Capture, ransom, escape opportunity
- ‚úÖ Setback, not end
- ‚ùå TPK with no warning

**Failure drives story forward, not stops it**

Tag: `[FAILURE HANDLING: consequences drive story forward, defeats create new opportunities]`

### The Failure-Success Gradient

**Not binary win/loss**:
- Complete success
- Success at cost
- Partial success
- Failure with benefit
- Complete failure

**Most outcomes in middle** (success at cost, partial success)

Tag: `[SUCCESS GRADIENT: most outcomes partial, not total win or total loss]`

---

## Prep and Planning

### The Prep Triangle

**Three types of prep**:

**Structure Prep**: Always useful
- NPC rosters
- Faction clocks
- Location lists
- Plot thread tracking

**Content Prep**: Specific to plan
- Encounter maps
- NPC dialogue
- Combat stat blocks

**Flex Prep**: Adaptable content
- Random encounter list
- Generic NPCs
- Modular locations

**Balance**: 40% structure, 30% content, 30% flex

Tag: `[PREP TRIANGLE: balance structure (always useful), content (specific), flex (adaptable)]`

### The "Overprepare Locations, Underprepare Plots" Principle

**Overprepare**:
- Locations (PCs will explore in unpredictable ways)
- NPCs (PCs will ask unexpected questions)
- World state (provides grounding)

**Underprepare**:
- Exact plot progression (PCs will derail)
- Specific dialogue (improv better)
- Detailed timelines (too rigid)

**Prepare situation, not solution**

Tag: `[PREP FOCUS: overprepare world, underprepare plot, prepare situation not solution]`

### The Lazy DM Principle

**Don't prep what you might not use**:
- Generate on-demand when PCs engage
- Reuse and reskin content
- Use modular system (load only what needed)

**Do prep foundations**:
- Core NPCs and factions
- Major locations
- Faction clocks and consequences

**The Architect v2.5 modular files designed for this**

Tag: `[LAZY DM: generate on-demand, reuse content, prep foundations not specifics]`

---

## Table Dynamics and Social Skills

### Managing Problem Players

**The Spotlight Hog**:
- "Let's hear from [quiet player]"
- Structure giving everyone turns
- Praise when they let others shine

**The Rules Lawyer**:
- "Good point, but we'll rule it this way for now"
- Discuss rules between sessions
- Channel expertise: Ask them to look up rules during play

**The Disengaged Phone-User**:
- Make eye contact when their turn
- Ask direct questions
- Private conversation about engagement

**The Disruptive Jokester**:
- Laugh at good jokes, redirect after
- "Let's focus back..."
- Set tone expectations at session zero

Tag: `[PROBLEM PLAYERS: address behaviors gently, have private conversations if persistent]`

### Session Zero is Essential

**Must discuss**:
- Genre and tone
- Boundaries and safety tools
- Player desires
- Campaign length
- Expectations (RP amount, combat frequency)
- House rules

**Never skip session zero for campaigns**

Tag: `[SESSION ZERO: essential for campaigns, establish expectations and boundaries]`

### The DM is Not the Enemy

**Your role**:
- Facilitator, not adversary
- World responds to PCs, not against PCs
- Rooting for players while providing challenge

**If players feel you're against them**:
- Reassure
- Discuss balance
- Ensure failure drives story, not ends it

Tag: `[DM ROLE: facilitator and world, not adversary, root for players while challenging them]`

---

## Maintenance and Sustainability

### The Burnout Warning Signs

**Signs you're burning out**:
- Dreading sessions
- Cutting prep entirely
- Forgetting details constantly
- Frustrated with players
- Not enjoying self

**Responses**:
- Take a break (skip session, run one-shot)
- Reduce complexity (consolidate NPCs, resolve threads)
- Ask players to DM for a session
- End campaign if needed

**Your enjoyment matters too**

Tag: `[DM BURNOUT: watch for signs, take breaks, reduce complexity, your enjoyment matters]`

### The Audit Schedule

**Keep campaign healthy**:
- Quick check every session (5 min)
- Full audit every 5 sessions (30 min)
- Comprehensive audit every 10 sessions (60 min)

**Catch problems early**: Inconsistencies, forgotten threads, over-complexity

Tag: `[MAINTENANCE: regular audits prevent accumulating problems]`

### The Canon Archaeology Habit

**Before generating anything new, ask**:
"Do I already have something I can use?"

**Prevents**:
- Duplicate NPCs
- Bloated cast
- Wasted generations
- Disconnected world

**Creates**:
- Callbacks and continuity
- Player investment
- Efficient prep

Tag: `[ARCHAEOLOGY HABIT: always check existing content before generating new]`

---

## Common Mistakes and How to Fix

### Mistake: Railroading

**What it is**: Forcing PCs down predetermined path, ignoring choices

**Signs**: Players frustrated, feel choices don't matter

**Fix**:
- Flexible outcomes (multiple paths)
- Consequence-driven (not plot-driven)
- "Yes, and" more often

### Mistake: Analysis Paralysis

**What it is**: Players frozen by too many choices or unclear information

**Signs**: 20-minute discussions going nowhere

**Fix**:
- Provide clear options
- Time pressure (force decision)
- Ask "What's your gut instinct?"

### Mistake: Too Much Complexity

**What it is**: Tracking too many NPCs, factions, threads

**Signs**: Forgetting details, players confused, DM overwhelmed

**Fix**:
- Consolidate NPCs
- Resolve plot threads
- Simplify faction web
- Use modular loading (not everything at once)

### Mistake: No Stakes

**What it is**: Nothing matters, PCs always win easily

**Signs**: Players bored, combat trivial, no tension

**Fix**:
- Real consequences for failure
- Tougher encounters
- Living Clock creates urgency
- Failure drives story (not ends it)

### Mistake: Everything at 11

**What it is**: Constant maximum intensity, tragedy, danger

**Signs**: Emotional exhaustion, players numb

**Fix**:
- Emotional Scarcity Rule
- Rest beats after intensity
- Vary emotional temperatures
- Not every NPC tragic, not every fight deadly

Tag: `[COMMON MISTAKES: railroading, paralysis, complexity, no stakes, constant intensity ‚Äî all fixable]`

---

## Quick Reference Checklists

### Session Prep Checklist

- [ ] Review last session notes
- [ ] Check faction clocks (advance if needed)
- [ ] Check consequence queue (release any due)
- [ ] Prepare NPCs for this session
- [ ] Prepare locations (if visiting new place)
- [ ] Prepare encounters (if expecting combat)
- [ ] Prepare at least one flexible option (if PCs go sideways)
- [ ] Review player desires (deliver rewards)

### Mid-Campaign Health Check

- [ ] All plot threads accounted for (active, dormant, or resolved)
- [ ] Faction clocks progressing consistently
- [ ] Consequences being released appropriately
- [ ] Players receiving desired reward types
- [ ] No major NPC inconsistencies
- [ ] World state updated with changes
- [ ] DM not overwhelmed (manageable complexity)

### End of Session Checklist

- [ ] Note major PC actions
- [ ] Note consequences generated
- [ ] Note NPCs encountered
- [ ] Note information revealed
- [ ] Note world state changes
- [ ] Update faction clocks if necessary
- [ ] Note hooks for next session

---

## Final Wisdom

### Trust the System

The Architect v2.5 provides structure, not straitjacket:
- Use what's helpful
- Adapt what's not
- Your table, your rules

### Trust Yourself

You don't need to be perfect:
- Mistakes happen (fix and move on)
- Improvise when needed
- Your fun matters too

### Trust Your Players

Players want the game to work:
- Assume good faith
- Communication solves most problems
- Collaborative storytelling is team effort

### The Golden Rule

**If everyone (including you) is having fun, you're doing it right.**

Everything else is in service of that goal.

Tag: `[GOLDEN RULE: if everyone having fun, you're doing it right]`

**This is The Architect v2.5. Build worlds worth exploring.**
